# Dot plots {.unnumbered} :::: {.callout-note collapse="false" icon=false} ## Graph info ::: {style="font-size: 1.25em; color: #02577A;"} **Should I use this graph?** :::
::: {.cell layout-align="right"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](dot_plots_files/figure-html/full_code_display-1.png){fig-align='right' width=60% height=60%} ::: ::: ::: {style="font-size: 1.10em; color: #02577A;"} **This graph requires:** ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.90em; color: #043b67;"} ✅ a numeric (continuous) variable ::: :::: ## Description Dot-plots are similar to histograms and frequency polygons, except instead of using bars or lines, they use dots to represent the frequency (or count) of values for a given variable. ## Getting set up :::: {.panel-tabset} ### Packages ::: {style="font-size: 1.15em; color: #1e83c8;"} **PACKAGES:** ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"} Install packages. ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.75em;"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} install.packages("palmerpenguins") library(palmerpenguins) library(ggplot2) ``` ::: ::: ### Data ::: {style="font-size: 1.15em; color: #1e83c8;"} **DATA:** ::: ::: {.column-margin} ![Artwork by Allison Horst](../www/lter_penguins.png){fig-align="right" width="100%" height="100%"} ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"} The `penguins` data ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.75em;"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} penguins <- palmerpenguins::penguins glimpse(penguins) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Rows: 344 Columns: 8 $ species Adelie, Adelie, Adelie, Adelie, Adelie, Adelie, Adel… $ island Torgersen, Torgersen, Torgersen, Torgersen, Torgerse… $ bill_length_mm 39.1, 39.5, 40.3, NA, 36.7, 39.3, 38.9, 39.2, 34.1, … $ bill_depth_mm 18.7, 17.4, 18.0, NA, 19.3, 20.6, 17.8, 19.6, 18.1, … $ flipper_length_mm 181, 186, 195, NA, 193, 190, 181, 195, 193, 190, 186… $ body_mass_g 3750, 3800, 3250, NA, 3450, 3650, 3625, 4675, 3475, … $ sex male, female, female, NA, female, male, female, male… $ year 2007, 2007, 2007, 2007, 2007, 2007, 2007, 2007, 2007… ``` ::: ::: ::: :::: ## The grammar :::: {.panel-tabset} ### Code ::: {style="font-size: 1.15em; color: #1e83c8;"} **CODE:** ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"} Create labels with `labs()` Initialize the graph with `ggplot()` and provide `data` Map `flipper_length_mm` to the `x` axis Add the `geom_dotplot()` layer Adjust the `dotsize` ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.75em;"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="show"} labs_dotplot <- labs( title = "Adult foraging penguins", subtitle = "Distribution of flipper length", x = "Flipper length (millimeters)") ggp2_dotplot <- ggplot(data = penguins, aes(x = flipper_length_mm)) + geom_dotplot(dotsize = 0.5) ggp2_dotplot + labs_dotplot ``` ::: ::: ### Graph ::: {style="font-size: 1.15em; color: #1e83c8;"} **GRAPH:** ::: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](dot_plots_files/figure-html/create_graph_dotplot-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"} A downside of using dot plots is the lack of interpretability of the `y` axis. ::: ::::
